timeline.body:
When I was in Alexa, we had some tests that used AWS services to do TTS and ASR. This was a ~fair external verification, since they were ~separate services. Here, we don't have such an external verification mechanism.

However, we do have mechanisms to:
1. Convert text to speech;
2. Convert speech to text.

you can have a test that does the "does speech to text work?" by providing an input wav, and expecting some valid text back.

For the "convert text to speech," you can assume the "speech to text" part works. Then do:
1. Arrange some text.
2. Act: convert it to speech.
3. Run speech to text (assuming that this component works), and get text back.
4. Assert that the returned text is ~close to the arranged text.

replies.bodyText: iOS's core VoiceType doesn't contain anything about language. Strangely enough, even the plugin's extension doesn't seem to contain language code (outside of the constant name that is), which means that they won't be able to support bilingual TTS feature.
replies.author: raphkim

replies.bodyText:
Since it wasn't clear whether the intention was to completely remove language from the equation or if they wanted to keep core VoiceType as generic as possible, I decided to keep the core VoiceType interface match up with iOS and only introduce the language code in the plugin specific voice type.
This allows us to support bilingual voices by separating AWSVoiceType#HINDI_ADITI and AWSVoiceType#INDIAN_ENGLISH_ADITI

timeline.body:
Apparently [languageCode is an optional parameter](https://github.com/aws-amplify/aws-sdk-android/blob/09ccb6110232c8103dcb5037f34840f1c2240261/aws-android-sdk-polly/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/polly/model/SynthesizeSpeechRequest.java#L47-L68), and if you don't include it, multilingual voices will fall back to a default language.  I guess this is how iOS is able to not include this parameter at all, and still have a mostly working implementation.  

I like that we now have multilingual support for Android.  I'd suggest reaching out to iOS and suggesting that they add similar support.
